Well, sadly few things have changed since I last tried it on b.net.

There are some upsides to Overwatch 2. Among it are a cadre of [b]superbly[/b] well-crafted heroes you can play, down to right the newest ones. Their visuals, their animations, and in particular their sound- and voice-work are [b]phenomenal[/b]. Most of the maps are also beautifully done, really bringing out the work done with the characters.

Further, the core gameplay loop of the game modes is really well thought out, in particular OW's spin on payload where you first have to capture the payload to start pushing it is good.

However, the game is marred by two extremely big issues.

First, and probably well-known at this point, is the [b]extreme[/b] level of microtransactions - and calling them that is questionable considering skins cost up to 20‚Ç¨ a piece and even individual voicelines cost you 1-3‚Ç¨ - that pervades the entire design. Everything is built to funnel you towards spending money, the game has essentially switched design-focus from a game with a store to now being a store that just happens to have a game attached. I cannot overstate just [b]how[/b] bad this feels compared to the old paid-for game that was Overwatch 1. Even ignoring the comparison however, the new store-centric design forces Blizzard to make more and more and more vivid and outrageous skins and visuals, which in turn takes a [b]huge[/b] chunk out of the superb visual design I mentioned above.

Second, they still have not even scratched the surface of the rebalancing needed after the removal of a second tank and the reduction from 6v6 to 5v5 in the switch-over to Overwatch 2. Sure, many elements work. But balance is all over the place, and importantly significantly worse compared to the previous game outside of eSports situations, and even there just barely better. It's a shame, because there [b]are[/b] good ideas in there, but as expected these come with a need to go back to the drawing board with [b]all[/b] heroes, doing sweeping rebalances all-over, and Blizzard has so fare only made small~moderate reworks and comparatively minor adjustments. Which were good, don't get me wrong, but as said before, it barely scratches the surface of what is needed.

So, overall, sadly I still cannot recommend the game at all. I loved Overwatch 1, I enjoyed some of the ideas behind Overwatch 2, but the game just doesn't feel like something remotely release-ready. Feels like an early-ish beta.

This review is being typed by someone who has played the game since release day May 3rd, 2016. Overwatch 2‚Ñ¢, when you strip away any controversies, is a fantastic Free-to-Play hero shooter. Looking at the game through the eyes of a brand new player, there's a good chance that you will enjoy your time with the game! You may fall in love with the art style or maybe heroes and their backgrounds. The cast of heroes is expansive and there is a hero for everyone! There is a good reason why the original title won 2016s Game of the Year! You will undoubtly come across alot of hate for the game which for all intent and purposes is completely justified!

Lets talk about some of that hate. Despite Overwatch 2‚Ñ¢ being a well-polished game, there are a bunch of issues that the community has with its current state. For starters, a whole list of broken promises. Overwatch 2‚Ñ¢ was originally supposed to be this highly replayable PvE with hero customization that you could sink hours and hours into. The game was supposed to be this complete story package. Unfortunately that vision was not able to be met. The story mode component has now been shoehorned into the predatory monetization model that was introduced with the converstion of the original Overwatch‚Ñ¢ into Overwatch 2‚Ñ¢ and will be drip-fed over the course of the games lifecycle. Speaking of the monetization model, expect to be met with battle passes and $20+ 'bundles' when you open up the 'Shop' tab on the main menu. There is currently no way to earn Premium currency (the currency to purchase battle passes and shop skins). The original Overwatch‚Ñ¢ handled monetization a bit differently. The original utilized 'loot boxes'. This system wasn't too bad though! You would earn a box everytime you leveled up. You also had a chance to receive credits that could be saved up to purchase any skin in the game! Alot of old players are used to this system. It allowed these players to own every cosmetic in the game.

Moving on, another point of contention is the removal of a handful of original Overwatch‚Ñ¢ features. Some examples would include account progression, post match voting system, a PTR server for testing new and upcoming changes/heroes, 'On fire' system (recently added back via Overwatch 2‚Ñ¢s season 5), and many more features. The community hopes that most, if not, all of these systems will return in future updates to the game.

In conclusion, Overwatch 2‚Ñ¢ is a fantasic and addictive game that will keep you entertained for hours on end. If you are brand new to this game and have never played it before, I highly recommend downloading it and giving it a shot!

Well. I played since OW1. And This is. OW1 just with a "Fresh" Coat of new Paint over it and a 2 slapped onto it.
They Promised so much. We Pre-orderd like good lemmings. And now? Now i still play TF2. 
OW2 PVE? Yeah... but behind a Paywall... wait... diden't we pay for PVE? DIDEN'T WE PAY ~40-60‚Ç¨? Where did that go?
In 1 Battlepass. Three new Heros... and One new Mode. 
1 Pass, 3 Heros and some new Maps? Oh and some Mid Tier Skins. Now they want EVEN More Money to Play the "Story" Mission? You got to be shitting me. 
Do yourself a Favor. If you like the Game Play it. But for the love of god. Dont Stuff their Throat with Money. The Devs deserve it... but i dont wanna know how much they get from it. Not really a Level System, No real Reward for leveling up like in the First Game in case of a Lootbox (A Keyless Create you get for EVERY level up) to get Skins. Nah you have to pay RL Money. "But they give you-" What One Skin out of how many? And tell me. How much do you think its worth? Exactly.
Nothing.
Like i said. Play if you want. But i realy hate that it fell of so hard. A Franchise died on lies, cut Promises and ignorance. 
Well imma hop into Dustbowl. See ya. And Have fun i guess.

For my review, I will hit the base points.

First.
They give you objectively awful characters, unless you play an insane amount of games (You need to play 25 full matches to unlock one of the meh support characters, which is about 3 hours at least of gaming) and then for other characters you need to do Call Of Duty Black Ops 3 easter egg gameplay to get, along with 3 hours of gameplay. 
Or you can just give them a bunch of money to get what should be a completely free character. 
They also only give you like 12, of the 40 or so. 

Second. 
Man I love having to pay for a battlepass to get literally anything including characters, you know, the entire thing the entire game is built around, which is extremely stupid to have to do. 

Third.
I love my enemies using their funny full roster of characters to kill me because I am forced to play the one class that literally cannot beat them in any engagement ever, because they paid over 40 dollars for all of them. 

Fourth.
It's just a bad game with absolutely horrendous business practice. They make it as much fun as going to the dentist and they begin drilling into your teeth without giving you novocaine or anything else to numb the pain.

I played one match with people, it froze for 5 seconds, I pressed D and W once, and was instant transmissioned through a wall and teleported while apparently running 90 feet into nothing, then fell into an instant killbox, which then froze my game and it crashed. 
Best first match I could ever ask for.

I entered the Overwatch universe through its second installment, primarily due to friends. Not having experienced the first game, I was eager for Overwatch 2's launch. Sadly, my excitement was overshadowed by the letdown of unfulfilled PvE promises. Instead of substantial improvements, we got weekly PvE missions that mirrored the ones in Overwatch 1. The introduction of paid options for skins that used to be free in Overwatch 1 felt like a bait-and-switch. The Overwatch 2 release with minimal advancements left me questioning the choices made by the developers.

My experience with matchmaking has been frustrating. It struggles to pair players of equal skill, resulting in an unsatisfying gameplay environment. Furthermore, the change from 6-player teams to 5-player teams feels imbalanced and has had a negative impact on my overall enjoyment.

While playing Overwatch 2 with friends has had its enjoyable moments, the unfulfilled promises and the issues with matchmaking and team balance have left me feeling cheated by the developers/publisher. This makes it hard for me to recommend the game wholeheartedly.

cat

Once upon a time, I had a cat, I had ten dollars, I would buy it food for eight dollars, bathe it often, and it was very sticky to me.

Later, I took it out to play, passers-by thought it was cute, they fed it cat food, ham sausage, I was very unhappy because it was mine. I wanted to carry it home, but he broke away from me and meowed at the person who gave it good food, I hugged him a few times and he didn't go with me, and scratched me, so I turned around and left.....

Later, I came across it by chance on the road, and it was dirty. Passers-by will only give it good food and play with it, but they will not take it home and bathe it. It saw me and followed me home, I shut it out, it meowed outside the door, it was very uncomfortable, [h1] but I wouldn't want it anymore [/h1].
